conversation:
Fist Marcus: Ah. True Soul. How glad I am to see you again.
InternalNodeContext: Player revealed Marcus at the checkpoint.
Isobel: Not a step closer, Marcus. I'm warning you.
Fist Marcus: I don't know what your game is, but you can still redeem yourself if you follow my lead.

NodeContext: Anger in his voice.
Fist Marcus: My instructions are clear: take the girl to Ketheric. Alive.
Fist Marcus: True Soul. My instructions are clear: take the girl to Ketheric. Alive.
Player: Probe his thoughts for more information.
: True
Narrator: *A haunting face swims into your mind's eye, its instructions vivid in your mind: nothing is more important than bringing the girl - alive.*
Isobel: What's going on? If you have something to say, say it.
Player: Marcus is trying to kidnap you, Isobel. We're going to need to fight our way out of this one.

Fist Marcus: Ah. True Soul. How glad I am to see you again.
InternalNodeContext: Player revealed Marcus at the checkpoint.
Isobel: Not a step closer, Marcus. I'm warning you.
Fist Marcus: I don't know what your game is, but you can still redeem yourself if you follow my lead.

NodeContext: Anger in his voice.
Fist Marcus: My instructions are clear: take the girl to Ketheric. Alive.
Fist Marcus: True Soul. My instructions are clear: take the girl to Ketheric. Alive.
Player: I know. Let's do this.
Isobel: What's going on? If you have something to say, say it.
Player: Marcus is trying to kidnap you, Isobel. We're going to need to fight our way out of this one.

Isobel: CinematicNodeContext: Isobel kneeling at corpse
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel gets up
Isobel: What the hells is this?
Narrator: *Your tingling Urge knows her face - this is the cleric Sceleritas sent you to kill.*
Player: He was trying to kidnap you. I sensed the tadpole in his head.
Isobel: A tadpole? Maiden's milk - how could that be?
Player: I have no reason to lie. Marcus was a danger to you all.
: True
Isobel: In that case, I owe you a debt of gratitude.
Isobel: You're the True Soul from the gate, right? It's a good thing you were here. I'm Isobel. And we have much to discuss.
Player: I may be a True Soul, but I'm not like Marcus. The parasite doesn't control me.
Isobel: If I didn't believe it before, I certainly do now.
Isobel: Speaking of blessings... you'll be needing my protection spell.
Isobel: Let me guess: Jaheira's sent you to beg a protection spell off her favourite cleric.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: |Casts 'Protection from Good and Evil', but modified with Selunite (moon) magic to protect against the Shadowcurse specifically. Isobel can use the planned animations for this spell cinematically, or something bespoke as best fits the scene. (lighting tests in progree for clouds revealing the moon)

We see every present party member  take on a moon-like effect as a result of being targeted with the spell, which then fades as though absorbed by each of them. This gives them a special in-game status to protect them from the curse|

We see every present party member  take on a moon-like effect as a result of being targeted with the spell, which then fades as though absorbed by each of them. This gives them a special in-game status to protect them from the curse|
Narrator: *The blessing falls uneasily over your tainted body. You can't help but dream: to kill her would destroy all of Last Light. You yearn for it so deeply...*
Shadowheart: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Perfect.
Isobel: It'll make you immune to the lesser effects of the shadow curse, which will get you closer to the Towers.
Isobel: It won't be enough to protect you against areas of utter darkness, though - where the curse is strongest. This lantern should, though.
Player: Very nice of you, but I've been to Moonrise Towers already.
Isobel: You... have. Forgive me for gilding the lily. I suppose if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing into the night, there's work to be done there yet.
Isobel: I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Hold on - Marcus is a True Soul. He's here to kidnap you.

Narrator: *You don't sleep well, flitting between dreams and nightmares.*
Narrator: *Maybe you wake up because you know something is wrong. Or maybe you just get lucky.*
Astarion: ...Shit.
NodeContext: Hunched over the player's bedroll, about to bite someone, but they've just woken up and are looking up at you. More deadpan than urgent.
Astarion: No no - it's not what it looks like, I swear!
Astarion: I wasn't going to hurt you! I just needed - well, blood.
Narrator: *There, in dim firelight, you see him for what he really is: a vampire. A slave to sanguine hunger.*
Player: You were strangely concerned when we met the monster hunter in the swamp.
Astarion: It's not what you think - I'm not some monster!
Astarion: I feed on animals! Boars, deer, kobolds - whatever I can get.
Astarion: I'm just too slow right now. Too weak.
Astarion: If I just had a little blood, I could think clearer. Fight better. Please.
Narrator: *A strange sensation courses through you, and your companion's mind unfolds, secrets half-revealed.*
Player: Why didn't you tell me?
Astarion: At best, I was sure you'd say no. More likely, you'd ram a stake through my ribs.
Astarion: No, I needed you to trust me. And you can trust me.
Player: I do. I believe you.
Astarion: Thank you. Do you think you could trust me just a little further?
Astarion: I only need a taste, I swear.
Player: All right, but go too far and I'll drive a stake through your chest.
Astarion: Ah. Of course. I shall be gentle as a babe.
Astarion: Let's make ourselves comfortable, shall we?
NodeContext: Astarion gestures, inviting the player to lie down on the bedroll at his feet.
Narrator: *It's like a shard of ice into your neck - a quick, sharp pain that fades to throbbing numbness. Your breath catches, your pulse quickens.*
Player: Push him back.
: False
Narrator: *You try to push him back, but his grip just gets tighter. You can feel your blood racing, coursing through both your bodies.*
Player: Stop! It's too much.
: True
Astarion: Ah! Of course.
Astarion: I was just swept up in the moment.
Astarion: But it worked. I feel good. Strong. Happy!
Player: You almost killed me!
Astarion: But I didn't. And that's what matters.
Astarion: And look what you've gained. Together, we can take on the world.
Player: You need to leave my camp. Now.

Player: I'm not like you - I don't take orders from the Absolute's cronies.
Fist Marcus: We are all alike in Her service. Do as I say. The rewards will be great.
Isobel: What's going on? If you have something to say, say it.
Player: Marcus is trying to kidnap you, Isobel. We're going to need to fight our way out of this one.

Astarion: No, I needed you to trust me. And you can trust me.
Player: I do. I believe you.
Astarion: Thank you. Do you think you could trust me just a little further?
Astarion: I only need a taste, I swear.
Player: All right, but go too far and I'll drive a stake through your chest.
Astarion: Urgh! Gods! Another drop and I would've burnt a hole from lips to navel. I thought we had that fire under control?
Player: Must be the infernal engine. Sorry, Astarion, I can't help you.
Astarion: Clearly.
Astarion: Safe to say this will never happen again.
Astarion: I'll go and find something on four legs to eat, I suppose.
Astarion: See you in the morning.
Player: No. Leave and never return.

Narrator: *You don't sleep well, flitting between dreams and nightmares.*
Narrator: *Maybe you wake up because you know something is wrong. Or maybe you just get lucky.*

Astarion: I feed on animals! Boars, deer, kobolds - whatever I can get.
Astarion: I'm just too slow right now. Too weak.
Astarion: If I just had a little blood, I could think clearer. Fight better. Please.

Isobel: CinematicNodeContext: Isobel kneeling at corpse
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel gets up
Isobel: What the hells is this?
Narrator: *Your tingling Urge knows her face - this is the cleric Sceleritas sent you to kill.*
Player: He was trying to kidnap you. I sensed the tadpole in his head.
Isobel: A tadpole? Maiden's milk - how could that be?
Player: I have no reason to lie. Marcus was a danger to you all.
: True
Isobel: In that case, I owe you a debt of gratitude.
Isobel: You're the True Soul from the gate, right? It's a good thing you were here. I'm Isobel. And we have much to discuss.
Player: I may be a True Soul, but I'm not like Marcus. The parasite doesn't control me.
Isobel: If I didn't believe it before, I certainly do now.
Isobel: Speaking of blessings... you'll be needing my protection spell.
Isobel: Let me guess: Jaheira's sent you to beg a protection spell off her favourite cleric.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: |Casts 'Protection from Good and Evil', but modified with Selunite (moon) magic to protect against the Shadowcurse specifically. Isobel can use the planned animations for this spell cinematically, or something bespoke as best fits the scene. (lighting tests in progree for clouds revealing the moon)

We see every present party member  take on a moon-like effect as a result of being targeted with the spell, which then fades as though absorbed by each of them. This gives them a special in-game status to protect them from the curse|

We see every present party member  take on a moon-like effect as a result of being targeted with the spell, which then fades as though absorbed by each of them. This gives them a special in-game status to protect them from the curse|
Narrator: *The blessing falls uneasily over your tainted body. You can't help but dream: to kill her would destroy all of Last Light. You yearn for it so deeply...*
Shadowheart: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Perfect.
Isobel: It'll make you immune to the lesser effects of the shadow curse, which will get you closer to the Towers.
Isobel: But there are places it won't help - places where the curse is darker. Stronger.
Isobel: The cultists are able to traverse even the deepest shadows, though. I don't know how - the Harpers are trying to figure it out.
Shadowheart: Selûnite magic. Dark Lady forgive me.
NodeContext: Low-key revulsion
Isobel: Good nose. Like a nasty little terrier.
Player: I already have a Moonlantern. I can safely travel the shadows.
Isobel: Well! Now you have two. Just in case.
Isobel: I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Hold on - Marcus is a True Soul. He's here to kidnap you.

Volo: I was just settling in and reviewing my latest findings. Mind flayers, cultists, and of course, your esteemed company!
Player: Has your research turned up anything that might help with this parasite problem?
Volo: My research turned up a rather brilliant technique that seems quite actionable.
Volo: The creature's in your brain, somewhere behind the orbital socket. I could attempt to remove it. I've a needle in my tunic...
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Volo pulls out a needle
~Volo hovers over the player holding a needle by their eye
~Volo hovers over the player holding a needle by their eye
Player: Do it.
Narrator: *Volo carefully holds one of your eyes open and begins to prod uncertainly with the needle.*
~Needle prodding idle
Player: Endure the discomfort. Let him carry on.
Narrator: *The needle finds the gap between eyeball and socket. Volo frowns and begins to push.*
Player: Clench your fists.
Narrator: *Pain shoots through your body as the needle snags on your optic nerve.*
Volo: I think I have it!
Narrator: *The needle see-saws back and forth, plucking the nerve like a harp string.*
Volo: Oh bother. There's some obstacle in the way. I shall need a more robust implement.
Player: Hold as still as possible.
Narrator: *Volo carefully withdraws the needle from your eye. Then, reaching into his bag, he produces an ice pick.*
~Volo hovers over the player holding an ice pick by their eye, reverse grip
Player: No, no. This is too much. Knock it off.
Volo: Are you certain? We're nearly there...
Player: Eye the implement, but allow him to proceed.

Narrator: *Volo slowly brings the ice pick closer to your eye.*
Volo: Now. Don't move.
Player: Hold your breath.
Narrator: *Cold metal presses against the skin beneath your brow, and then...*

Lunkbug: Oh Beldron... I'm so sorry. I'll get you out of there. I promise.
Player: I have news: half the trapped gnomes are already dead.
Lunkbug: Great gods. How - how could you know that?
Player: I'm a True Soul. I saw them through Nere's eyes.
Apprentice Laridda: You - you can do that? I mean of course. Of course, True Soul.
Apprentice Laridda: Th-thank you for sharing, truly.
Lunkbug: Damn it, Laridda. We've lost enough of us. I'm not losing Beldron, too.
Lunkbug: Hear me out - our friends are trapped in the cave-in. And I know a way to get them out.
Apprentice Laridda: Bug, please. True Soul Nere will - you know what he'll do.
Player: That sounds like quite the drama. I can't wait to watch.
Apprentice Laridda: What? No. Lunkbug, you can't.
NodeContext: Pleading with Lunkbug not to say anything.
Lunkbug: I've... I've got no choice, Laridda. We have to chance it.
Lunkbug: A few days back, there was a... a scene. Our friend Philomeen, she's a sapper. Set off a blast and ran off.
Lunkbug: We set a spot for hiding if someone found trouble. I'll mark your map.
Lunkbug: If Philomeen made it, you'll find her there. She'll have the stuff to blow that tunnel wide open and get Beldron and the rest out.
Gale: If we're to help Thulla, we'll have to breach that wall with explosives and hope the blast doesn't injure anyone. Or worse.
Player: I'll do what I can.

Cora Highberry: Roger, look, a visitor!
Roger Highberry: Ah, so I see. Are we expecting anyone, Cora?
Cora Highberry: No - the grocer's just been, as has the chandler. Then there's your tailor - he's due soon to get the children outfitted for the festival...
Roger Highberry: And of course, the Wine Festival itself is but a few days away - Cora, we do forget ourselves! We've not even asked this fine young stranger's name.
Player: A wine festival sounds charming.
Cora Highberry: We hope so, it's going to be right on our doorstep!
Roger Highberry: The festival was put together to raise funds for the children, you see. Times are a touch tough at the moment.

Viconia DeVir: Finish it. Send me to Lady Shar's embrace.
Shadowheart: She still has answers I need.
Player: Make it quick.
Shadowheart: My parents. Where are they?
Viconia DeVir: So blunt - have you forgotten all the interrogation techniques I taught you? Where is the finesse?
Shadowheart: Answer me!
Viconia DeVir: They are right through that door, in the Chamber of Loss. Where they have been all along. You saw them many times, only we made you forget. But they didn't forget.
Viconia DeVir: They watched, as we moulded you. They watched. They wept. They bled - often at your hand. It may not be a happy reunion, but it will be a memorable one.
Player: Such cruelty...
Shadowheart: Why? Why me? Why all this effort?
Viconia DeVir: Lady Shar commanded me. And I obeyed. I do not question - I merely act as she wills me to.
Viconia DeVir: I had an enclave in Waterdeep, you know. Much grander than this. Shar ordered me to raze it, kill all who followed me - claim they betrayed me, when in fact I slew those who showed nothing but loyalty.
Viconia DeVir: Shar had me do that, and I did. To cover my tracks. To usher in you.
Shadowheart: What are you talking about?
Viconia DeVir: You became my mission. To take a child of Selûne's, and turn her over to Lady Shar. To show that all light fades, and darkness will prevail in the end.
Viconia DeVir: All this was to make you into what the Dark Lady needed you to be - the planning. The training. Those deaths in Waterdeep. It was all to groom you to replace me at her right hand side. And still, you threw it away.
Player: What do you want to do, Shadowheart?
Shadowheart: I want to see my parents. And I don't care what happens to this one. She's been in my head long enough already. Do what you like. I know you'll choose well.
Viconia DeVir: What are you doing? Come back and finish this yourself! You owe me that!
Shadowheart: Let go, Mother. Embrace loss.
Jaheira: She stands at the same crossroads you yourself once did, Viconia - but it seems you are not quite the teacher you thought.
Minsc: Boo thinks you have had every chance to change your ways. Count yourself blessed it is not he who judges you today.
Player: Go. If you're wise, you'll vanish.

Kirgrath: Shit. Brithvar's kicked the tankard. Prick was older than dirt.

Kirgrath: Listen up, Clan Flameshade - we need to cut and run.

Player: By the sundering - the parasite allows us to influence others.
Player: Taking away the free will of others - could be a gift, or a curse in disguise.
Player: A power born of illithids might be dangerous in the wrong hands, but valuable in ours.
Player: Its value is unproven and I'm not sure I want to prove it, one way or another. It's an illithid parasite after all.
Player: If this power comes from these parasites, it can't be trusted. However useful it might be.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: [opening, face-to-face]

Wyll and Karlach stand facing one another, fists clenched.

Wyll and Karlach stand facing one another, fists clenched.
Wyll: One horn. The stink of Avernus. Advocatus diaboli.
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you.
Wyll: Karlach. The archdevil Zariel's gladiator, come to burn the Sword Coast to ash.
Player: You've got it all wrong, Wyll. Karlach's not about to hurt anyone.
Karlach: Well - not counting the fuckers that need a good hurting.
Wyll: Shut it, devil - I know your kind. A heart darker than a shadow's nightmares. You'd cut a child's throat just to taste the blood.
Karlach: A devil? I didn't take the Blade for a fool. I'm - ngh!
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.*
Narrator: *You are Karlach, tearing through demons across a blood-red landscape of fire and volcanic cinder.*
Narrator: *The front lines of the Blood War. With every swing of her axe, Karlach fulfils mistress Zariel's purpose.*
Wyll: Proof, clear as summer sky. It's over, Karlach. It's time you feel the sting of the Blade.
Karlach: I've tried to tell you - I'm not what you think I am.
Narrator: *Another vision. Karlach's blade raised, slicing through devils - Zariel's servants - as her eyes dart around, seeking escape.*
Narrator: *Wyll shudders with Karlach's desperation. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Wyll: By Balduran's helm, I - no. I will not be tricked!
Karlach: You saw the truth. I may be an effective soldier, but I never wanted to serve Zariel. Legged it away from her the first chance I got.
Wyll: And yet you served.
Player: Be practical. She's infected, same as us. We need allies, not enemies.
: False
Wyll: No. Devils can not be trusted!
Player: You're right. Let's cut her down before she causes any trouble.

Shadow-Whiskers: Another? Good.
Player: That cage looks comfy.
Shadow-Whiskers: Mock me. Tease me. You will be the first.
Player: First in what? Come on - your secret is safe with me.
: True
Shadow-Whiskers: Look. See. The crowd - they laugh. They shine with innocence. But it is a lie.
Shadow-Whiskers: Every one of you is vicious. Cruel. You kill my mate. Steal my cubs.
Halsin: Poor creature - locked in a cage, denied her true nature. Civilisation would call her a monstrosity, yet it treats her like this...?
Shadow-Whiskers: I roar. Break my cage - and then you die. You all die.
Player: Break the lock, ensuring the cage can't be opened.

Araj Oblodra: Welcome back, True Soul.
Araj Oblodra: I read about your kind for so many years, but never thought I'd find one in real life. And to find such a fine specimen...
Astarion: Don't worry, we're all friends under the Absolute. I won't bite.
Araj Oblodra: Oh I'd prefer if you did.
Araj Oblodra: I assume he belongs to you?
Player: Excuse me? He's his own person.
Araj Oblodra: I'm sure he really believes that. How utterly adorable.
Araj Oblodra: Do you have a name, spawn?
Astarion: Astarion, but hold on-
Araj Oblodra: Good. Now, Astarion, I've dreamt of being bitten by a vampire since I was a young girl.
Astarion: I'm sorry? You want to be bitten?
Araj Oblodra: To feel your life's blood slipping away? To dance on the edge between life and death? Yes, I want it.
Araj Oblodra: I'll even compensate you - a potion of legendary power that forever increases the strength of the one who consumes it.
Araj Oblodra: It's not for sale, but it's yours if you bite me.
Astarion: I will have to decline.
Araj Oblodra: Excuse me? This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity and you're squandering it.
Astarion: I gave you my answer.
Araj Oblodra: Can't you talk some sense into your obstinate charge?
Player: Just bite her - the potion sounds useful.
Astarion: I'm sorry, but could you excuse us a moment?
Astarion: Are you actually asking me to do this? Trading me for some potion?
Astarion: Because there's something wrong with her blood. I can smell it from here - it's rank.
Player: Don't be dramatic, it's just a bite. One nip and you're done.
Astarion: Easy for you to say, you won't have to taste whatever sludge is in those veins.
Astarion: Fine, I'll do it.

Wyll and Karlach stand facing one another, fists clenched.

Wyll and Karlach stand facing one another, fists clenched.
Wyll: One horn. The stink of Avernus. Advocatus diaboli.

Wyll: Karlach. The archdevil Zariel's gladiator, come to burn the Sword Coast to ash.
Player: You've got it all wrong, Wyll. Karlach's not about to hurt anyone.

Karlach: A devil? I didn't take the Blade for a fool. I'm - ngh!
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.*
Narrator: *You are Karlach, tearing through demons across a blood-red landscape of fire and volcanic cinder.*
Narrator: *The front lines of the Blood War. With every swing of her axe, Karlach fulfils mistress Zariel's purpose.*
Wyll: Proof, clear as summer sky. It's over, Karlach. It's time you feel the sting of the Blade.
Karlach: I've tried to tell you - I'm not what you think I am.
Narrator: *Another vision. Karlach's blade raised, slicing through devils - Zariel's servants - as her eyes dart around, seeking escape.*
Narrator: *Wyll shudders with Karlach's desperation. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*

Karlach: You saw the truth. I may be an effective soldier, but I never wanted to serve Zariel. Legged it away from her the first chance I got.
Wyll: And yet you served.

The Warden: You. Not you. Lord Ketheric may think you pose no threat to him in your disgrace, but I know the things you've done.

The Warden: Your name, your place was kept from all of us last time, but you were to be shown the utmost of respect.
The Warden: Respect you must have proven yourself unworthy of. And now you waste my time.

The Warden: Whatever your business, a warning: none may speak to the prisoners - Disciple Balthazar was most clear.

Viconia DeVir: Finish it. Send me to Lady Shar's embrace.
Shadowheart: She still has answers I need.
Player: Let's kill her.
Shadowheart: First I need answers.
Shadowheart: My parents. Where are they?
Viconia DeVir: So blunt - have you forgotten all the interrogation techniques I taught you? Where is the finesse?
Shadowheart: Answer me!
Viconia DeVir: They are right through that door, in the Chamber of Loss. Where they have been all along. You saw them many times, only we made you forget. But they didn't forget.
Viconia DeVir: They watched, as we moulded you. They watched. They wept. They bled - often at your hand. It may not be a happy reunion, but it will be a memorable one.
Player: She's just trying to rile you up.
Shadowheart: I know. But she's not lying. She made me in her image.
Shadowheart: Why? Why me? Why all this effort?
Viconia DeVir: Lady Shar commanded me. And I obeyed. I do not question - I merely act as she wills me to.
Viconia DeVir: I had an enclave in Waterdeep, you know. Much grander than this. Shar ordered me to raze it, kill all who followed me - claim they betrayed me, when in fact I slew those who showed nothing but loyalty.
Viconia DeVir: Shar had me do that, and I did. To cover my tracks. To usher in you.
Shadowheart: What are you talking about?
Viconia DeVir: You became my mission. To take a child of Selûne's, and turn her over to Lady Shar. To show that all light fades, and darkness will prevail in the end.
Viconia DeVir: All this was to make you into what the Dark Lady needed you to be - the planning. The training. Those deaths in Waterdeep. It was all to groom you to replace me at her right hand side. And still, you threw it away.
Player: What do you want to do, Shadowheart?
Shadowheart: I want to see my parents. And I don't care what happens to this one. She's been in my head long enough already. Do what you like. I know you'll choose well.
Viconia DeVir: What are you doing? Come back and finish this yourself! You owe me that!
Shadowheart: Let go, Mother. Embrace loss.
Jaheira: She stands at the same crossroads you yourself once did, Viconia - but it seems you are not quite the teacher you thought.
Minsc: Boo thinks you have had every chance to change your ways. Count yourself blessed it is not he who judges you today.
Player: Go. If you're wise, you'll vanish.

Wyll and Karlach stand facing one another, fists clenched.

: True

Player: Hold your breath.

Gondian Zanner Toobin: Narn'guth kree'shav da'lor.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Your nervous gait betrays your presence, stranger. You don't belong here. Who are you?
Player: I've come to free you - I already dealt with some of the Banites.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Blek'ith! Why?
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Your presence imperils us all. If any of us attempts to escape, our kin will die.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: The overseers - they have a contraption. When triggered, it will kill everyone who wears a collar.
Player: Can't you remove the collars?
Gondian Zanner Toobin: You underestimate the enemy. The overseers, they are glix'bran rak'tharr.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: The collars are not only equipped with explosives, there is also a mechanism that alerts the overseers if they're removed.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: One of us may be able to save themselves, but it would be at the expense of everyone else. We can't risk it.
Player: It's worth the risk - worst case scenario, you die fighting.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: If it were only our lives on the line, we'd have rebelled long ago.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Our families are held elsewhere. The overseers need only activate those contraptions they hold, and they suffer the consequences of our actions too.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: We cannot win. We must aid in building these vargh'kron.
Player: It's selfish to value your families more than an entire city.

Archivist: A guest? Are you a client of the master, or a visitor from elsewhere in the Hells?
Archivist: I do not believe you were invited. One moment - I shall consult the visitors' schedule.
Archivist: Hmmm.
Archivist: HMMMM.
: True
Narrator: *His eyes flicker back and forth as if he is reading a book. He has the schedule memorised... or it's carved into his eyelids.*
Archivist: Most irregular. The schedule is all but clear. And yet you are here.
Player: I'm a client of Raphael's, and had second thoughts about the terms of my deal.
Archivist: I commend you! Thinking is a marvellous pastime.
Archivist: You should have third, fourth, and fifth thoughts about your deal as well. You can think about all the ways you're never going to break it.
Player: How about I break bits of you until you tell me how to get what I want?
: False
Archivist: There are few bits of me that haven't been broken already.
Archivist: You're more than welcome to do your very worst. I'll have the guards stop you if it starts to tickle.

Player: Pay him.
Brem: He's all yours. Don't forget to feed him - he bawls something proper.

Viconia DeVir: Finish it. Send me to Lady Shar's embrace.
Shadowheart: She still has answers I need.
Player: Let's kill her.
Shadowheart: First I need answers.
Shadowheart: My parents. Where are they?
Viconia DeVir: So blunt - have you forgotten all the interrogation techniques I taught you? Where is the finesse?
Shadowheart: Answer me!
Viconia DeVir: They are right through that door, in the Chamber of Loss. Where they have been all along. You saw them many times, only we made you forget. But they didn't forget.
Viconia DeVir: They watched, as we moulded you. They watched. They wept. They bled - often at your hand. It may not be a happy reunion, but it will be a memorable one.
Player: Such cruelty...
Shadowheart: Why? Why me? Why all this effort?
Viconia DeVir: Lady Shar commanded me. And I obeyed. I do not question - I merely act as she wills me to.
Viconia DeVir: I had an enclave in Waterdeep, you know. Much grander than this. Shar ordered me to raze it, kill all who followed me - claim they betrayed me, when in fact I slew those who showed nothing but loyalty.
Viconia DeVir: Shar had me do that, and I did. To cover my tracks. To usher in you.
Shadowheart: What are you talking about?
Viconia DeVir: You became my mission. To take a child of Selûne's, and turn her over to Lady Shar. To show that all light fades, and darkness will prevail in the end.
Viconia DeVir: All this was to make you into what the Dark Lady needed you to be - the planning. The training. Those deaths in Waterdeep. It was all to groom you to replace me at her right hand side. And still, you threw it away.
Player: What do you want to do, Shadowheart?
Shadowheart: I want to see my parents. And I don't care what happens to this one. She's been in my head long enough already. Do what you like. I know you'll choose well.
Viconia DeVir: What are you doing? Come back and finish this yourself! You owe me that!
Shadowheart: Let go, Mother. Embrace loss.
Jaheira: She stands at the same crossroads you yourself once did, Viconia - but it seems you are not quite the teacher you thought.
Minsc: Boo thinks you have had every chance to change your ways. Count yourself blessed it is not he who judges you today.
Player: Go. If you're wise, you'll vanish.

Araj Oblodra: I read about your kind for so many years, but never thought I'd find one in real life. And to find such a fine specimen...

Astarion: Because there's something wrong with her blood. I can smell it from here - it's rank.

Astarion: I already have enough illithid filth in my head - I don't want it in my stomach as well.

The Warden: You. Not you. Lord Ketheric may think you pose no threat to him in your disgrace, but I know the things you've done.
The Warden: Keep your bloody thoughts to yourself and your head down.
Player: How in the Hells do you know me?

The Warden: I assumed you overstayed your welcome. Little did I expect you to intrude again.
The Warden: Your name, your place was kept from all of us last time, but you were to be shown the utmost of respect.
The Warden: Respect you must have proven yourself unworthy of. And now you waste my time.
The Warden: Hm. Perhaps not - your face is rather bland.
The Warden: Whatever your business, a warning: none may speak to the prisoners - Disciple Balthazar was most clear.

Pixie is visualized by a glowing light, not a physical body

Araj Oblodra: Welcome back, True Soul.
Araj Oblodra: I read about your kind for so many years, but never thought I'd find one in real life. And to find such a fine specimen...
Astarion: Don't worry, we're all friends under the Absolute. I won't bite.
Araj Oblodra: Oh I'd prefer if you did.
Araj Oblodra: I assume he belongs to you?
Player: Excuse me? He's his own person.
Araj Oblodra: I'm sure he really believes that. How utterly adorable.
Araj Oblodra: Do you have a name, spawn?
Astarion: Astarion, but hold on-
Araj Oblodra: Good. Now, Astarion, I've dreamt of being bitten by a vampire since I was a young girl.
Astarion: I'm sorry? You want to be bitten?
Araj Oblodra: To feel your life's blood slipping away? To dance on the edge between life and death? Yes, I want it.
Araj Oblodra: I'll even compensate you - a potion of legendary power that forever increases the strength of the one who consumes it.
Araj Oblodra: It's not for sale, but it's yours if you bite me.
Astarion: I will have to decline.
Araj Oblodra: Excuse me? This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity and you're squandering it.
Astarion: I gave you my answer.
Araj Oblodra: Can't you talk some sense into your obstinate charge?
Player: Just bite her - the potion sounds useful.
Astarion: I'm sorry, but could you excuse us a moment?
Astarion: Are you actually asking me to do this? Trading me for some potion?
Astarion: Because there's something wrong with her blood. I can smell it from here - it's rank.
Player: A potion that powerful could change our fates. Isn't that worth a bad taste in your mouth?
Astarion: I... I suppose you have a point.
Astarion: Fine, I'll do it.

Shadow-Whiskers: Another? Good.
Player: That cage looks comfy.
Shadow-Whiskers: Mock me. Tease me. You will be the first.
Player: Tell me what you're up to or I set this cage on fire.
: True
Shadow-Whiskers: Look. See. The crowd - they laugh. They shine with innocence. But it is a lie.
Shadow-Whiskers: Every one of you is vicious. Cruel. You kill my mate. Steal my cubs.
Halsin: Poor creature - locked in a cage, denied her true nature. Civilisation would call her a monstrosity, yet it treats her like this...?
Shadow-Whiskers: I roar. Break my cage - and then you die. You all die.
Player: Break the lock, ensuring the cage can't be opened.

Gondian Zanner Toobin: Narn'guth kree'shav da'lor.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Your nervous gait betrays your presence, stranger. You don't belong here. Who are you?
Player: I've come to free you - I already dealt with some of the Banites.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Blek'ith! Why?
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Your presence imperils us all. If any of us attempts to escape, our kin will die.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: The overseers - they have a contraption. When triggered, it will kill everyone who wears a collar.
Player: Can't you remove the collars?
Gondian Zanner Toobin: You underestimate the enemy. The overseers, they are glix'bran rak'tharr.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: The collars are not only equipped with explosives, there is also a mechanism that alerts the overseers if they're removed.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: One of us may be able to save themselves, but it would be at the expense of everyone else. We can't risk it.
Player: Rise up in unison - they can't stop you all.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Even if we did somehow unshackle our collars simultaneously, and overthrow our oppressors, there would be consequences.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Our families are held elsewhere. The overseers need only activate those contraptions they hold, and they suffer the consequences of our actions too.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: We cannot win. We must aid in building these vargh'kron.
Player: It's selfish to value your families more than an entire city.

Volo: I was just settling in and reviewing my latest findings. Mind flayers, cultists, and of course, your esteemed company!
Player: Has your research turned up anything that might help with this parasite problem?
Volo: My research turned up a rather brilliant technique that seems quite actionable.
Volo: The creature's in your brain, somewhere behind the orbital socket. I could attempt to remove it. I've a needle in my tunic...
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Volo pulls out a needle
~Volo hovers over the player holding a needle by their eye
~Volo hovers over the player holding a needle by their eye
Player: Do it.
Narrator: *Volo carefully holds one of your eyes open and begins to prod uncertainly with the needle.*
~Needle prodding idle
Player: Do you have the faintest idea of what you're doing?
Volo: Don't fidget! The needle must slip behind your eye, not through it!
Narrator: *The needle finds the gap between eyeball and socket. Volo frowns and begins to push.*
Player: Clench your fists.
Narrator: *Pain shoots through your body as the needle snags on your optic nerve.*
Volo: I think I have it!
Narrator: *The needle see-saws back and forth, plucking the nerve like a harp string.*
Volo: Oh bother. There's some obstacle in the way. I shall need a more robust implement.
Player: Hold as still as possible.
Narrator: *Volo carefully withdraws the needle from your eye. Then, reaching into his bag, he produces an ice pick.*
~Volo hovers over the player holding an ice pick by their eye, reverse grip
Player: Eye the implement, but allow him to proceed.

Narrator: *Volo slowly brings the ice pick closer to your eye.*
Volo: Now. Don't move.
Player: Hold your breath.
Narrator: *Cold metal presses against the skin beneath your brow, and then...*

Manip Bakshi: What in the Nine bloody Hells is going on? Reynash?
Manip Bakshi: You've got one breath to explain why you're in here, or you're going straight to the cells.

: True

Manip Bakshi: That sneaky little git. It was him all along?

Manip Bakshi: Now unless you want me pinning this on you - get out!

Harper Branthos: Be safe. And be brave. We expect no less.

: True
: True

Lorna Esthelian: Ah - a friendly face at last. Are you going to the party as well?
Player: A party in the sewers?
Lorna Esthelian: I know. Bit strange, isn't it? But then you have to be open to trying new things.
Lorna Esthelian: The venue's called 'The Palace'. Not sure what it stands for, but it sounds very exclusive.
Lorna Esthelian: My date's supposed to meet me here, but there's no sign of him.
Lorna Esthelian: You haven't seen him, have you? Pale, skinny - extremely piercing eyes.
: True
Narrator: *The individual descriptions could refer to many things, but taken together, she can only be referring to something vampiric in nature.*
Lorna Esthelian: It's funny. He was ever so keen for me to come. He didn't seem the type to cancel...
Player: You've had a very lucky escape. Your date was a vampire.

Varsh Ko'kuu: This hatchery is a place of solemn duty and care. No one approaches an egg without my permission.
Varsh Ko'kuu: Of course, a stranger from a strange crèche may have different customs. What brings you here?
Player: I am here to help you save the egg.
Varsh Ko'kuu: This egg is in my care. It does not need saving.
Varsh Ko'kuu: It is a little slower to hatch, nothing more.
Lae'zel: Failure at the first hurdle of existence. Most caretakers would crush it and be done.
Varsh Ko'kuu: Most caretakers would not give the child its fair chance, but I shall. There could be greatness in that shell.
: True
Narrator: *You note that the hope in his voice is tinged with weariness. It's the voice of a man who's fought the inevitable for a long time.*
Player: This seems like an awful lot of fuss for one egg.
Varsh Ko'kuu: Kith'rak Therezzyn is of the same opinion. She would see it destroyed and forgotten.
Varsh Ko'kuu: I'll give it a while longer, and if it doesn't hatch - it will have proven her right.

Crimson: You - you freed me from hunger's lust.
Crimson: Forgive me. I was close to killing you - killing everyone. I am ashamed.
Player: I'd have killed you before you hurt anyone here.

Viconia DeVir: Finish it. Send me to Lady Shar's embrace.
Shadowheart: She still has answers I need.
Player: Let's kill her.
Shadowheart: First I need answers.
Shadowheart: My parents. Where are they?
Viconia DeVir: So blunt - have you forgotten all the interrogation techniques I taught you? Where is the finesse?
Shadowheart: Answer me!
Viconia DeVir: They are right through that door, in the Chamber of Loss. Where they have been all along. You saw them many times, only we made you forget. But they didn't forget.
Viconia DeVir: They watched, as we moulded you. They watched. They wept. They bled - often at your hand. It may not be a happy reunion, but it will be a memorable one.
Player: This is a waste of time. Kill her.
Shadowheart: No, you should keep them talking as long as you can, then you kill them. She taught me that.
Shadowheart: Why? Why me? Why all this effort?
Viconia DeVir: Lady Shar commanded me. And I obeyed. I do not question - I merely act as she wills me to.
Viconia DeVir: I had an enclave in Waterdeep, you know. Much grander than this. Shar ordered me to raze it, kill all who followed me - claim they betrayed me, when in fact I slew those who showed nothing but loyalty.
Viconia DeVir: Shar had me do that, and I did. To cover my tracks. To usher in you.
Shadowheart: What are you talking about?
Viconia DeVir: You became my mission. To take a child of Selûne's, and turn her over to Lady Shar. To show that all light fades, and darkness will prevail in the end.
Viconia DeVir: All this was to make you into what the Dark Lady needed you to be - the planning. The training. Those deaths in Waterdeep. It was all to groom you to replace me at her right hand side. And still, you threw it away.
Player: What do you want to do, Shadowheart?
Shadowheart: I want to see my parents. And I don't care what happens to this one. She's been in my head long enough already. Do what you like. I know you'll choose well.
Viconia DeVir: What are you doing? Come back and finish this yourself! You owe me that!
Shadowheart: Let go, Mother. Embrace loss.
Jaheira: She stands at the same crossroads you yourself once did, Viconia - but it seems you are not quite the teacher you thought.
Minsc: Boo thinks you have had every chance to change your ways. Count yourself blessed it is not he who judges you today.
Player: Go. If you're wise, you'll vanish.

Lae'zel: Honoured kith'rak. May Vlaakith show us truth.

Shadowheart: I sincerely hope you know what you're doing...

Araj Oblodra: Welcome back, True Soul.
Araj Oblodra: I read about your kind for so many years, but never thought I'd find one in real life. And to find such a fine specimen...
Astarion: Don't worry, we're all friends under the Absolute. I won't bite.
Araj Oblodra: Oh I'd prefer if you did.
Araj Oblodra: I assume he belongs to you?
Player: Excuse me? He's his own person.
Araj Oblodra: I'm sure he really believes that. How utterly adorable.
Araj Oblodra: Do you have a name, spawn?
Astarion: Astarion, but hold on-
Araj Oblodra: Good. Now, Astarion, I've dreamt of being bitten by a vampire since I was a young girl.
Astarion: I'm sorry? You want to be bitten?
Araj Oblodra: To feel your life's blood slipping away? To dance on the edge between life and death? Yes, I want it.
Araj Oblodra: I'll even compensate you - a potion of legendary power that forever increases the strength of the one who consumes it.
Araj Oblodra: It's not for sale, but it's yours if you bite me.
Astarion: I will have to decline.
Araj Oblodra: Excuse me? This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity and you're squandering it.
Astarion: I gave you my answer.
Araj Oblodra: Can't you talk some sense into your obstinate charge?
Player: I am surprised, Astarion. I thought you'd jump at a chance like this.
Astarion: I'm sorry, but could you excuse us a moment?
Astarion: Are you actually asking me to do this? Trading me for some potion?
Astarion: Because there's something wrong with her blood. I can smell it from here - it's rank.
Player: What do you mean? What's wrong with her blood?
Astarion: I can't say, it just smells wrong. Unnatural.
Astarion: Drinking it wouldn't kill me, but it would not be pleasant.
Araj Oblodra: I don't have all day, True Soul.
Player: Just suck it up and bite her already.
Astarion: Fine, I'll do it.

Volo: I was just settling in and reviewing my latest findings. Mind flayers, cultists, and of course, your esteemed company!
Player: I want help with my parasite. By any means necessary.
Volo: The creature's in your brain, somewhere behind the orbital socket. I could attempt to remove it. I've a needle in my tunic...
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Volo pulls out a needle
~Volo hovers over the player holding a needle by their eye
~Volo hovers over the player holding a needle by their eye
Player: Do it.
Narrator: *Volo carefully holds one of your eyes open and begins to prod uncertainly with the needle.*
~Needle prodding idle
Player: Endure the discomfort. Let him carry on.
Narrator: *The needle finds the gap between eyeball and socket. Volo frowns and begins to push.*
Player: Clench your fists.
Narrator: *Pain shoots through your body as the needle snags on your optic nerve.*
Volo: I think I have it!
Narrator: *The needle see-saws back and forth, plucking the nerve like a harp string.*
Volo: Oh bother. There's some obstacle in the way. I shall need a more robust implement.
Player: Hold as still as possible.
Narrator: *Volo carefully withdraws the needle from your eye. Then, reaching into his bag, he produces an ice pick.*
~Volo hovers over the player holding an ice pick by their eye, reverse grip
Player: Eye the implement, but allow him to proceed.

Narrator: *Volo slowly brings the ice pick closer to your eye.*
Volo: Now. Don't move.
Player: Stop. This is never going to work.
Volo: Are you sure? If I don't intervene, the parasite will continue to gestate inside you.
Player: I don't have much choice then. Fine, continue.
Narrator: *Cold metal presses against the skin beneath your brow, and then...*

Viconia DeVir: So you think you have won? Time will tell - far easier to claim something than hold onto it.
Viconia DeVir: They will turn on you, in time. When you hear the whispers, and see the blades drawn, remember my face.

Minsc: Boo thinks you have had every chance to change your ways. Count yourself blessed it is not he who judges you today.
Player: Go. If you're wise, you'll vanish.

Lunkbug: Oh Beldron... I'm so sorry. I'll get you out of there. I promise.
Player: I have news: half the trapped gnomes are already dead.
Lunkbug: Great gods. How - how could you know that?

Apprentice Laridda: Th-thank you for sharing, truly.
Lunkbug: Damn it, Laridda. We've lost enough of us. I'm not losing Beldron, too.
Lunkbug: Hear me out - our friends are trapped in the cave-in. And I know a way to get them out.
Apprentice Laridda: Bug, please. True Soul Nere will - you know what he'll do.

Apprentice Laridda: What? No. Lunkbug, you can't.
NodeContext: Pleading with Lunkbug not to say anything.

Lunkbug: A few days back, there was a... a scene. Our friend Philomeen, she's a sapper. Set off a blast and ran off.
Lunkbug: We set a spot for hiding if someone found trouble. I'll mark your map.
Lunkbug: If Philomeen made it, you'll find her there. She'll have the stuff to blow that tunnel wide open and get Beldron and the rest out.
Karlach: Perfect. Let's get a move on, then.
Player: I'll do what I can.

The Warden: Keep your bloody thoughts to yourself and your head down.
Player: How in the Hells do you know me?

The Warden: Your name, your place was kept from all of us last time, but you were to be shown the utmost of respect.
The Warden: Respect you must have proven yourself unworthy of. And now you waste my time.
The Warden: Hm. Perhaps not - your face is rather bland.
The Warden: Whatever your business, a warning: none may speak to the prisoners - Disciple Balthazar was most clear.

: False

Wulbren Bongle: Your friend is some smooth talker to shut a guard down like that. What do you lot want with me, exactly?
Wulbren Bongle: You ordered that guard about as if you were the Absolute herself. What do you want with us, exactly?
Player: I'm here to help you escape.
Wulbren Bongle: Huh. And why would you be so inclined?
Player: Fine, die in here for all I care.

Wyll: You were a marvel to behold! Even Balduran himself would bow to such formidable talent.
Wyll: Introductions are in order. The Blade of Frontiers, at your...
Narrator: *The man's smile bends downward, and his thoughts become yours.*
Narrator: *You are the Blade of Frontiers, racing through the wastes of Avernus. Just ahead, a diabolical figure - red skin, single curled horn - blazes with flame, bloodied greataxe held high.*
Narrator: *It's Karlach - the woman you met in the wilds.*
Wyll: Hells' great fires - you were on the ship.
Player: Yes - and we both carry parasites.
Wyll: Mm - doomed to shed our skin and become illithid, or so the stories go.
Wyll: But I haven't sprouted any tentacles - not yet, anyway. Nor have you. Could just be good luck. I'm not so...
Narrator: *Your minds collide once more. Wyll chases the fiend, ignited with rancour. She is an infernal wardevil, a threat to the living - evil incarnate.*
Wyll: Shit - you saw her: advocatus diaboli.
: False
Narrator: *Advocatus diaboli. A devil's advocate - a champion in the Blood War between diabolical forces and demons.*
Player: I met a group of paladins who were also seeking this devil.
Wyll: I'm not surprised. My target is well-known for her brutality in service of her evil mistress.
Wyll: Karlach is an archdevil's soldier I swore on my good eye to kill.
Wyll: I tracked her through the Hells to the mind flayer ship. But the damned illithids infected me before I could end her.
Wyll: She's out there now, preying on the innocent. I don't kill her, she'll leave behind nothing but a trail of corpses.
Player: Let's join forces. I'll help you cast this devil back into the Hells.

Varsh Ko'kuu: I don't have time to parent you as well. What do you want now?

Gondian Zanner Toobin: Narn'guth kree'shav da'lor.

Gondian Zanner Toobin: The overseers - they have a contraption. When triggered, it will kill everyone who wears a collar.
Player: Can't you remove the collars?
Gondian Zanner Toobin: You underestimate the enemy. The overseers, they are glix'bran rak'tharr.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: The collars are not only equipped with explosives, there is also a mechanism that alerts the overseers if they're removed.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: One of us may be able to save themselves, but it would be at the expense of everyone else. We can't risk it.

Gondian Zanner Toobin: Our families are held elsewhere. The overseers need only activate those contraptions they hold, and they suffer the consequences of our actions too.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: We cannot win. We must aid in building these vargh'kron.

Volo: I was just settling in and reviewing my latest findings. Mind flayers, cultists, and of course, your esteemed company!
Player: Has your research turned up anything that might help with this parasite problem?
Volo: My research turned up a rather brilliant technique that seems quite actionable.
Volo: It's not too deep. Just behind the orbital socket. I could attempt an extraction. I've a needle in my tunic, after all...
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Volo pulls out a needle
~Volo hovers over the player holding a needle by their eye
~Volo hovers over the player holding a needle by their eye
Player: Do it.
Narrator: *Volo carefully holds one of your eyes open and begins to prod uncertainly with the needle.*
~Needle prodding idle
Player: Endure the discomfort. Let him carry on.
Narrator: *The needle finds the gap between eyeball and socket. Volo frowns and begins to push.*
Player: Clench your fists.
Narrator: *Pain shoots through your body as the needle snags on your optic nerve.*
Volo: I think I have it!
Narrator: *The needle see-saws back and forth, plucking the nerve like a harp string.*
Volo: Oh bother. There's some obstacle in the way. I shall need a more robust implement.
Player: Hold as still as possible.

Player: Eye the implement, but allow him to proceed.

Volo: Now. Don't move.
Player: Hold your breath.

Varsh Ko'kuu: This hatchery is a place of solemn duty and care. No one approaches an egg without my permission.
Varsh Ko'kuu: Of course, a stranger from a strange crèche may have different customs. What brings you here?
Player: I am here to help you save the egg.
Varsh Ko'kuu: This egg is in my care. It does not need saving.
Varsh Ko'kuu: It is a little slower to hatch, nothing more.
Lae'zel: Failure at the first hurdle of existence. Most caretakers would crush it and be done.
Varsh Ko'kuu: Most caretakers would not give the child its fair chance, but I shall. There could be greatness in that shell.
: True
Narrator: *You note that the hope in his voice is tinged with weariness. It's the voice of a man who's fought the inevitable for a long time.*
Player: This seems like an awful lot of fuss for one egg.
Varsh Ko'kuu: Kith'rak Therezzyn is of the same opinion. She would see it destroyed and forgotten.
Varsh Ko'kuu: I'll give it a while longer, and if it doesn't hatch - it will have proven her right.
Player: Why risk its life at all? Give it to me - I'll take care of it.
: True
Varsh Ko'kuu: You? You've no varsh instincts about you at all.
Varsh Ko'kuu: Still, the captain's due for an inspection any day now, and if she sees it here...
NodeContext: the captain will destroy his precious egg if she finds it
Varsh Ko'kuu: Tell me, what will you do with it if I entrust it to you?
Player: I'll find another crèche. One that's more forgiving.

Cora Highberry: Roger, look, a visitor!
Roger Highberry: Ah, so I see. Are we expecting anyone, Cora?
Cora Highberry: No - the grocer's just been, as has the chandler. Then there's your tailor - he's due soon to get the children outfitted for the festival...
Roger Highberry: And of course, the Wine Festival itself is but a few days away - Cora, we do forget ourselves! We've not even asked this fine young stranger's name.
Player: I'm [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53].  And you are?
Cora Highberry: I am Cora Highberry, and this is my husband, Roger. Delighted to meet you.
Roger Highberry: More than delighted! A little extra company's always welcome as we enter our twilight years - yet another reason we're putting on the wine festival!
Player: 'Another' reason? Why else would you run a wine festival?
Roger Highberry: The festival was put together to raise funds for the children, you see. Times are a touch tough at the moment.
Player: Which children are you raising money for?
Roger Highberry: Young Molly and Timothy, who we've recently taken charge of. Their parents... Well. War leaves the nastiest scars.
Player: Perhaps a small donation would help salve those scars? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Player: So the tadpole gives us the ability to influence others... Huh.

Player: It could be a good thing though, right? The only way we'll find out is by trying it out.

Nightwarden Minthara: I expected to be greeted as a hero - but the wretches imprisoned me, and tried to tear my mind apart.
Nightwarden Minthara: I didn't think anyone would come for me.
Player: What were they doing to you?
Nightwarden Minthara: Erasing my thoughts, and my will. Even I could not have endured for much longer.
Player: I came here for the pleasure of killing you myself.

True Soul Gut: Now, here's somebody special. The Absolute has touched you, hasn't She?
True Soul Gut: Priestess Gut needs to touch you, too - hold out your arm so I can mark your flesh.
Player: Why should I let you brand me?
True Soul Gut: Lets the faithful recognise one another quick-sharp. That way, nobody'll mess with you.
True Soul Gut: An' it's charged with magic. Ordinary slobs can't see it; only us that follow the Absolute.
Gale: Charged with magic? Perhaps that explains the ease with which these goblins submit to True Souls.
True Soul Gut: You ready? Brace yourself - this'll sting.
Player: Hold out your hand.

Viconia DeVir: Finish it. Send me to Lady Shar's embrace.
Shadowheart: She still has answers I need.
Player: Make it quick.
Shadowheart: My parents. Where are they?
Viconia DeVir: So blunt - have you forgotten all the interrogation techniques I taught you? Where is the finesse?
Shadowheart: Answer me!
Viconia DeVir: They are right through that door, in the Chamber of Loss. Where they have been all along. You saw them many times, only we made you forget. But they didn't forget.
Viconia DeVir: They watched, as we moulded you. They watched. They wept. They bled - often at your hand. It may not be a happy reunion, but it will be a memorable one.
Player: This is a waste of time. Kill her.
Shadowheart: No, you should keep them talking as long as you can, then you kill them. She taught me that.
Shadowheart: Why? Why me? Why all this effort?
Viconia DeVir: Lady Shar commanded me. And I obeyed. I do not question - I merely act as she wills me to.
Viconia DeVir: I had an enclave in Waterdeep, you know. Much grander than this. Shar ordered me to raze it, kill all who followed me - claim they betrayed me, when in fact I slew those who showed nothing but loyalty.
Viconia DeVir: Shar had me do that, and I did. To cover my tracks. To usher in you.
Shadowheart: What are you talking about?
Viconia DeVir: You became my mission. To take a child of Selûne's, and turn her over to Lady Shar. To show that all light fades, and darkness will prevail in the end.
Viconia DeVir: All this was to make you into what the Dark Lady needed you to be - the planning. The training. Those deaths in Waterdeep. It was all to groom you to replace me at her right hand side. And still, you threw it away.
Player: What do you want to do, Shadowheart?
Shadowheart: I want to see my parents. And I don't care what happens to this one. She's been in my head long enough already. Do what you like. I know you'll choose well.
Viconia DeVir: What are you doing? Come back and finish this yourself! You owe me that!
Shadowheart: Let go, Mother. Embrace loss.
Jaheira: She stands at the same crossroads you yourself once did, Viconia - but it seems you are not quite the teacher you thought.
Minsc: Boo thinks you have had every chance to change your ways. Count yourself blessed it is not he who judges you today.
Player: Go. If you're wise, you'll vanish.

Disciple Z'rell: The goblins - tell me how they suffered.
Disciple Z'rell: No. Better yet - show me.
Narrator: *Her mind enters yours abruptly, flickering across your memories in a blaze of excitement.*
Narrator: *A pool of warmth spreads through your mind as she settles on the memory of you commanding the goblins to die.*
Disciple Z'rell: Oh, I like you. That was inventive, and efficient.
Player: And enjoyable. Got any more minions to punish?
Disciple Z'rell: Plenty. But I hoped someone of your talents would be more ambitious.
Disciple Z'rell: You came here to answer the Absolute's call. Let's see what you're made of.
Narrator: *She parts the folds of your mind again, touching your wants and hopes. Tasting them.*
Narrator: *Every emotion soaks into her mind's palate, but there is purpose to her exploration - she is searching for proof of your faith.*
Player: Distract her with your yearning for Gale.
: True
Disciple Z'rell: Hmmmm. You have used the wizard well.
Disciple Z'rell: But the desperate one who would love such a pathetic man must hunger for greater delights, deep down.
Disciple Z'rell: With the Absolute, your fantasies can become more real than flesh. The pleasures of the mind can surpass those of the body.
Disciple Z'rell: I have already been blessed to stand in Her presence. It was bliss.
Disciple Z'rell: She gave me everything I wanted.
Player: Show me the power She gave you.
Disciple Z'rell: Oh, why not? What's the point in power if you don't get to have a little fun every now and again?
Disciple Z'rell: She gave me the power to cut the thread of life with a thought.
Disciple Z'rell: But I can caress as well as cut. That's why you should stay on my good side.

Karlach: Could have sworn I told you to piss off. Maybe I imagined it.

Karlach: Anyhow. Piss off.
Player: I met the people looking for you - and killed them.
Karlach: Oh. Sorry I told you to piss off just now. Come on over here - we should talk.
Player: They said you're a fiend, that you belong in hell.
Karlach: If you killed them, I'm guessing you didn't buy their bullshit.
Karlach: I don't belong in hell any more than you do. But I was there.
Narrator: *As she winces, agony shoots through you, as if your bodies share the same wound.*
Narrator: *Then you're lost in visions of demonic armies, as you tear through a landscape of fire and blood.*
Narrator: *The Blood War. You saw it from above as the nautiloid passed through Avernus - this woman was on the frontline.*
Karlach: Ster'ca. What was that? You were inside my head...
NodeContext: ster'ca (stir-KA (very harsh KA)) is a curse word in infernal language. She's shocked, a little afraid of us
Player: It wasn't me - it's the parasites from the mind flayer ship. They connected us.
Karlach: Hold on a minute - you were on that ship? With the tentacles, and the worms?
Karlach: I didn't think anyone else had survived.
Player: I didn't see you aboard. Where were you?
Karlach: I boarded in Avernus - that ship was my way out.
Player: You must have got clear of the crash site in a hurry.
Karlach: You're lucky I did.
Karlach: The place would have been crawling with cultists if I'd stuck around - and they'd have dragged us all back to Avernus.
Karlach: And I'll be going straight back if those imp-fuckers catch me.
Player: Why were you in hell in the first place?
Karlach: I was a prisoner, forced to fight in the Blood War - the eternal battle between bad and worse.
Karlach: Most souls in Avernus are just meat for the grinder. But not me.
Karlach: I held my own. More than. Turns out I've got a knack for killing demons - and I enjoy it. That made me a valuable asset.
Karlach: Devils don't like to lose their assets.
Player: How can I help?
Karlach: A gang of cultists cornered me in an abandoned tollhouse, not far from here.
Karlach: I took out a couple, but I need them all dead.
Player: If I do this, what do I get in return?
Karlach: You get a friend who spat in Baphomet's eye and lived to tell the tale.
Player: I'll do it.

Narrator: *Calmness greets you as the submersible slows to a halt. Unlike the Iron Throne, you remain intact.*
Narrator: *While the same cannot be said for most of the Gondian hostages, at least one of them survived.*
Narrator: *Duke Ravengard approaches you, looking confused.*
GROUP_Emperors: He's tadpoled, but under my protection now, just like you. His mind is his own again.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: I'm... free. In my own mind again, wholly. I will not take it for granted.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You have my gratitude, friend - you acted quickly, decisively. No soul who fell here did so in vain. I will honour their sacrifice.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You acted quickly, decisively, and compassionately. I - nay, all of us - owe you no less than our undying gratitude.
Player: How did you end up in the Iron Throne?
Duke Ulder Ravengard: It's where Gortash stores his playthings. His keepsakes. But I am his trinket no longer.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My thoughts are my own now, and my purpose certain. I will wait at your camp - we can speak more there.

Mol: Go on, enjoy yourself. But if any of them sleep past noon they're getting left behind.
Player: I didn't touch the idol. Don't know what happened to it.
: False
Mol: You're a terrible liar. We had a deal.
Player: Here's some free advice: never bargain, just take what's yours.

Bex: Please, I just want to be alone.
Player: I remember you - Bex, right? Where's your man?
Bex: Gone.
Bex: Cultists... It was so dark I didn't realise until the children started screaming.
Bex: They rounded us up... cut us up... Said they were taking whoever could still walk to Moonrise Towers.
Bex: I managed to get away, but my love Danis... Mar zindur vroshan.
Player: How did you manage to get away?
Bex: I've always been good at running - unlike Danis.
Bex: I didn't realise one day our lives would depend on it.
Bex: I just wish I could have said goodbye.
Player: Is there anything I can do to help?
Bex: Not unless you can bring him back.
Bex: Can you?
Bex: I wish I hadn't let go of him.
Player: I'll find Danis and bring him back to you.

Zarys: You're the one who recruited me, Rugan.
NodeContext: She's overseeing the torture of an agent of hers - one who originally recruited her to the organisation. Tone is chiding and also vaguely disgusted - he should have known better.
Zarys: You're the one who taught me rule number one, remember?
NodeContext: As if reflecting on 'good old days', but with a harder edge
Rugan: Bwaah.
Zarys: No. Olly didn't remember either, did you Olly?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Close-up of Olly lying on the floor - already tortured to death,
NodeContext: Olly is bound to a chair on the floor, tortued to death
NodeContext: Olly is bound to a chair on the floor, tortued to death
Zarys: You're dead the moment you steal from the Zhentarim.
Zarys: No matter who you are.
: True
Narrator: *You recall an old Zhentarim proverb coined by their founder.*
: False
Player: Dead of boredom listening to you, pipsqueak.
: True
Zarys: Hah - the fire in you! Maybe we wouldn't be here if Rugan had a little of that, eh?
NodeContext: Genuine laughter - you're threatening her gang despite the odds being heavily stacked against you. She's won over by it.
Zarys: Tell you what: you've already taken Rugan's cargo, so finish the job and I'll let you live. Deliver it to Baldur's Gate.
Zarys: Oh, and kill him.
Player: Obey - kill Rugan.

Efrin: Ungh... me head...
NodeContext: You were turned to stone and you're just coming out of it. Dazed, confused, touching your head.
Efrin: Oh no. No. Why ain't I petrified?
Player: The hag is dead.
Efrin: What?! How... how am I still breathin'?
Efrin: I've the Bite...
Player: Ha! The Bite should have turned you inside out by now.
Efrin: Better dead than a greyling. Why d'ya think we call it Laduguer's Bite? After that slaver of a god you adore?
Efrin: Because nothing disgusts us more than you lot.
Player: We 'greylings' know the Bite well - ask nicely, and I'll see how long you've got left.
Efrin: You do?
Efrin: I... could you have a look?
Player: Hmm? What was that?
Efrin: Could you have a look... please.
Player: Changed my mind. Enjoy tripping over your own guts.

Narrator: *The lantern gives off a chilly glow, protecting all in its vicinity from the surrounding shadows.*
Harper Branthos: Incredible magic. I can feel the light lifting the shadows - even those within me.
Harper Branthos: Be safe. And be brave. We expect no less.
Narrator: *You notice a tiny pixie trapped within.*
: True
Narrator: *These fey creatures were well known among druidic circles - for both their playful hijinks and malicious trickery.*

Pixie is visualized by a glowing light, not a physical body
Dolly Dolly Dolly: Oh please, oh golly, me-oh-my, you must release me or I'll die!
Dolly Dolly Dolly: This lantern only lights the way when I am hurting night and day!
Player: Who are you?
Dolly Dolly Dolly: My name? My name is Dolly thrice; now won't you free me from this vice?
Player: What's this mechanism at the base of the lantern?
Dolly Dolly Dolly: I dare not name it, newfound friend. The faintest touch could spell my end.
Player: Turn the mechanism.
Dolly Dolly Dolly: Son of a - NO! STOP! PLEASE!
Player: Unfortunately for you, I need this lamp fully functioning.
Dolly Dolly Dolly: I'LL GUT YOU LIKE A TEN-DAY-OLD IF YOU DON'T RELEASE ME RIGHT! THIS! MOMENT!

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I don't wish to study, only to lift the curse on this land.
Malus Thorm: A curse? Nay, a cure that leads to the very pinnacle of being:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.

Karlach: I don't belong in hell any more than you do. But I was there.

Narrator: *Then you're lost in visions of demonic armies, as you tear through a landscape of fire and blood.*

Karlach: I didn't think anyone else had survived.

Astarion: I've never even seen this face. Not since it grew fangs and my eyes turned red.

Astarion: I... I don't know. I can't remember.
Astarion: My face is just some dark shape in my past. Another thing I've lost.

Player: Stare into his eyes, taking in every detail of his face.

Astarion: This is meant to be flattery, not poetry. Just tell me I'm beautiful and we can call it a day.

Astarion: Mirrors aren't much use, but being reflected in someone else's eyes?
Astarion: Well, I could do worse.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: [SCENE] The player wakes up in the middle of the night to find Kith'rak Voss there, accompanied by one other gith. Voss holds his sword in a seemingly aggressive manner.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Lae'zel steps forward, confident.
Lae'zel: Supreme Kith'rak. Has Vlaakith sent you to slay me with your own blade?
Kith'rak Voss: I've not come to kill you, Lae'zel. I've come to aid you.
GROUP_Daisy: Don't trust him.

Player: Your cronies tried to kill us. Why should Lae'zel listen to you?
Kith'rak Voss: I knew you would fight - and I knew you would win. I needed to ensure Vlaakith's trust. This was the only way.
Kith'rak Voss: I know you carry the Astral Prism, Lae'zel.
Kith'rak Voss: Within it lies the seed of Vlaakith's demise. And I intend to help you bring it to fruition.
Lae'zel: Vlaakith's demise? Shka'keth. I should run you through for suggesting it.
Player: You must be either a fool or a hero to work against your own queen.
Kith'rak Voss: A fool stumbles without cause. A hero serves a cause without question.
Kith'rak Voss: I am neither. 'Clear of heart, clear of mind, and bound by no master.' Now - you must listen.
Kith'rak Voss: The Prism's tenant can put an end to Vlaakith's tyranny. They must be let loose.
Kith'rak Voss: I've sought their freedom for aeons. When the Prism went missing, I feared the worst.
Kith'rak Voss: Instead, you've granted the opportunity I've so long awaited.
Kith'rak Voss: All that remains is the key that unchains them - and I've found someone who I believe can provide it.
Kith'rak Voss: Bring the Prism to Baldur's Gate. I'll be waiting in a taproom called Sharess' Caress. That is where we decide the fate of my people.
Kith'rak Voss: Lae'zel - together we will break our chains, and be Vlaakith's slaves no longer.
Lae'zel: I am no slave, Jhe'stil Kith'rak. The Undying Queen is my freedom. It is she who will purify me, and she who will ascend me.
Kith'rak Voss: Lies, Lae'zel - every last one. There is no purification, no ascension.
Kith'rak Voss: The zaith'isk does not purify - it extracts memory and kills the infected. Nor does the lich queen glorify the ascended. She feeds on most all of them to grow her power and pursue godhood.
Lae'zel: Madness. You flood me with this... this heresy.
NodeContext: Not nearly as aggressive as usual. She believes him but is keeping up appearances.
Lae'zel: I... I will hear no more of it.
NodeContext: Rising alittle in anger but questioning. She is ready to be convinced. But she has to keep up appearances.
Player: Kill him. This is your chance to earn Vlaakith's redemption.

He Who Was: This woman tended a bar where she took her patrons, her friends, into her confidence - promised their secrets were safe with her.
He Who Was: Yet she turned their words into knives - and stabbed them in the back.
He Who Was: They died because of her - and to this day her victims lie unavenged.
Player: She's dead - how much more can she pay?
He Who Was: Death is not the end - merely another beginning.
He Who Was: I seek a record of this one's crimes - written in her own hand.
He Who Was: Through it, I can summon her spirit - and force her to face trial for her crimes.
Player: That's some powerful magic.
He Who Was: Not for one such as I.
He Who Was: Your soul sparks with vengeance. With fury. This is your chance to torment a murderer. To make her suffer.

Wyll and Karlach stand facing one another, fists clenched.

Wyll and Karlach stand facing one another, fists clenched.

Karlach: Well - not counting the fuckers that need a good hurting.

Narrator: *You are Karlach, tearing through demons across a blood-red landscape of fire and volcanic cinder.*
Narrator: *The front lines of the Blood War. With every swing of her axe, Karlach fulfils mistress Zariel's purpose.*
Wyll: Proof, clear as summer sky. It's over, Karlach. It's time you feel the sting of the Blade.
Karlach: I've tried to tell you - I'm not what you think I am.

Narrator: *Wyll shudders with Karlach's desperation. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*

Karlach: You saw the truth. I may be an effective soldier, but I never wanted to serve Zariel. Legged it away from her the first chance I got.
Wyll: And yet you served.

Wyll: You don't know what this means. You don't know what you're asking me to do.
Karlach: I'm asking you to live, Wyll. I don't want to hurt you. And, to be frank, I'd rather not find out how the Blade got his name.
Karlach: I swear to you, on all I am, I'm not what you think.

Wyll: You really are no devil, are you? I've... I've been deceived.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I don't wish to study, only to lift the curse on this land.
Malus Thorm: A curse? Nay, a cure that leads to the very pinnacle of being:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: 'Only with sacrifice is mastery gained.' For the sisters to learn, you must submit.
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes. Submit I must, into the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Malus Thorm: I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

Bex: They rounded us up... cut us up... Said they were taking whoever could still walk to Moonrise Towers.
Bex: I managed to get away, but my love Danis... Mar zindur vroshan.
Player: It sounds like he meant a lot to you.
Bex: Everything.
Bex: I just wish I could have said goodbye.
Player: Is there anything I can do to help?
Bex: Not unless you can bring him back.
Bex: Can you?
Bex: I wish I hadn't let go of him.
