Viconia DeVir: Finish it. Send me to Lady Shar's embrace.
Shadowheart: She still has answers I need.
Player: Let's kill her.
Shadowheart: First I need answers.
Shadowheart: My parents. Where are they?
Viconia DeVir: So blunt - have you forgotten all the interrogation techniques I taught you? Where is the finesse?
Shadowheart: Answer me!
Viconia DeVir: They are right through that door, in the Chamber of Loss. Where they have been all along. You saw them many times, only we made you forget. But they didn't forget.
Viconia DeVir: They watched, as we moulded you. They watched. They wept. They bled - often at your hand. It may not be a happy reunion, but it will be a memorable one.
Player: She's just trying to rile you up.
Shadowheart: I know. But she's not lying. She made me in her image.
Shadowheart: Why? Why me? Why all this effort?
Viconia DeVir: Lady Shar commanded me. And I obeyed. I do not question - I merely act as she wills me to.
Viconia DeVir: I had an enclave in Waterdeep, you know. Much grander than this. Shar ordered me to raze it, kill all who followed me - claim they betrayed me, when in fact I slew those who showed nothing but loyalty.
Viconia DeVir: Shar had me do that, and I did. To cover my tracks. To usher in you.
Shadowheart: What are you talking about?
Viconia DeVir: You became my mission. To take a child of Selûne's, and turn her over to Lady Shar. To show that all light fades, and darkness will prevail in the end.
Viconia DeVir: All this was to make you into what the Dark Lady needed you to be - the planning. The training. Those deaths in Waterdeep. It was all to groom you to replace me at her right hand side. And still, you threw it away.
Player: What do you want to do, Shadowheart?
Shadowheart: I want to see my parents. And I don't care what happens to this one. She's been in my head long enough already. Do what you like. I know you'll choose well.
Viconia DeVir: What are you doing? Come back and finish this yourself! You owe me that!
Shadowheart: Let go, Mother. Embrace loss.
Jaheira: She stands at the same crossroads you yourself once did, Viconia - but it seems you are not quite the teacher you thought.
Minsc: Boo thinks you have had every chance to change your ways. Count yourself blessed it is not he who judges you today.
Player: Kill Viconia.

Astarion: Looking at something?

Player: How did you know I was here?
Astarion: The only benefit to a mirror when you have my condition.
NodeContext: Holds up a mirror to show how he could see you
Astarion: It doesn't quite make up for the lack of a reflection, mind you.
NodeContext: Astarion watches the player in the mirror as they move through the space where his reflection should be.
Player: Do you miss it? Seeing your own face?
Astarion: Preening in the looking glass? Petty vanity? Of course I miss it.

Astarion: I've never even seen this face. Not since it grew fangs and my eyes turned red.
Player: What colour were they before?
Astarion: I... I don't know. I can't remember.
Astarion: My face is just some dark shape in my past. Another thing I've lost.
NodeContext: He hurls the mirror to the ground.
Player: Stare into his eyes, taking in every detail of his face.
Astarion: What?
Player: I see you.
Astarion: And what do you see, exactly?
Player: Strong, piercing eyes.
Astarion: Oh. Go on...
Player: The way your hair curls around your ears.
Astarion: This is meant to be flattery, not poetry. Just tell me I'm beautiful and we can call it a day.
Player: Honestly, Wyll's more my type.
Astarion: How dare you! I thought we had something special.
Astarion: Still. You're nice too.
Astarion: I'd better get some beauty sleep. It seems I need it if I'm to catch up with the competition.

: False

Wulbren Bongle: I see Gondian propaganda is alive and well. We match the High House of Wonders in design. Innovation. Brilliance.
Wulbren Bongle: Yet they banished us from Baldur's Gate. And for what?
Wulbren Bongle: Yes, our forebears were complicit with Sarevok's madness. But it was a century ago, and nothing more than foolishness.
Wulbren Bongle: But our forebears were foolish - complicit with Sarevok's madness over a century past, and so we were banished. Still are to this day.
Player: Pity he never succeeded.

Demir: Bloody hells, she just disappeared. Ain't seen nothing like that before.

Player: Will someone please tell me what's going on?
Demir: It's our sister - Mayrina. She is... well, she was in a bad way after her husband died.
Johl: Started saying weird things, like how she was gonna bring him back.
Demir: Next thing, she's gone looking for the hag. Of all the stupid things to do.
Demir: We haven't seen her since, and no good ever came from dealing with a hag.
Johl: None of this matters, all right? We need to get her back. And fast.

Bex: I didn't realise one day our lives would depend on it.
Bex: I just wish I could have said goodbye.

Bex: I wish I hadn't let go of him.

Isobel: I had no dreams at all. Nothing but darkness. And when I awoke, my father said you were dead.
NodeContext: mirthless humor - reflecting on the bleak reality

NodeContext: with a smile

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I don't wish to study, only to lift the curse on this land.
Malus Thorm: A curse? Nay, a cure that leads to the very pinnacle of being:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I am not worthy! Please, show me how a master works - I would be honoured.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Jaheira then directs her stern glance at us. Without a word she raises her right hand claw-like to chest height. Magic ripples and entangling vines start to sprout from the ground, trapping the party in place. Onlooking Harpers draw their swords. |

Jaheira: You have me at a disadvantage. Let me correct that.
Jaheira: Hello.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Harpers draw their weapons.
Player: Please - ma'am - I'm from Baldur's Gate. Like you. I'm on your side.
Jaheira: I'll be the judge of that.
Jaheira: This is why we're here, you see.
NodeContext: Her calm menace continues. She’s about to make a demonstration.
Jaheira: It is a curious creature that hides all manner of secrets. But if there's one thing that we know -
NodeContext: Her calm menace continues. She’s about to make a demonstration.
Jaheira: - it's that it knows its own kind.

| (CINE) Her suspicions now confirmed, Jaheira stows away the jar. The onlooking Harpers eye us with a mixture of fear and hatred. |
NodeContext: Her calm menace continues. The demonstration is done and she’s proved her point: we’re the enemy because we have a tadpole in our heads.
Jaheira: You should never have come here, True Soul.
NodeContext: Grave. She’s passing a death sentence on us.

Mol: Stop!

| (CINE) Jaheira glances over as a small figure pushes through the Harpers. It's Mol. |
Mol: What are you doing? They're the ones that saved us!
Jaheira: They're the one who protected the Emerald Grove?
Mol: Yup. Didn't leave a goblin standing. Not so bad to hang around with either.
Mol: Saved two of my friends - one from a harpy, and one from a mad druid with a snake. Didn't make a fuss of our thieving, either.
Mol: I'd pretty much trust them with my life.
Jaheira: A True Soul with a mind of their own... How is that possible?
Jaheira: How is that possible?
Player: I work in mysterious ways.
Jaheira: Enlighten me. Now.
Jaheira: You sound so confident for someone who's so wrong.

: True

Jaheira: Hear me, Harpers! All clear, at ease!

Jaheira: I'll not pretend to understand why you, the enigma that you are, suddenly crossed our path, but I'm old and wise enough to recognise a sliver of hope when it crawls out of the dark.
Jaheira: Tell me - why have you come here?

Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you.
Wyll: Karlach. The archdevil Zariel's gladiator, come to burn the Sword Coast to ash.
Player: You've got it all wrong, Wyll. Karlach's not about to hurt anyone.
Karlach: Well - not counting the fuckers that need a good hurting.
Wyll: Shut it, devil - I know your kind. A heart darker than a shadow's nightmares. You'd cut a child's throat just to taste the blood.
Karlach: A devil? I didn't take the Blade for a fool. I'm - ngh!
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.*
Narrator: *You are Karlach, tearing through demons across a blood-red landscape of fire and volcanic cinder.*
Narrator: *The front lines of the Blood War. With every swing of her axe, Karlach fulfils mistress Zariel's purpose.*
Wyll: Proof, clear as summer sky. It's over, Karlach. It's time you feel the sting of the Blade.
Karlach: I've tried to tell you - I'm not what you think I am.
Narrator: *Another vision. Karlach's blade raised, slicing through devils - Zariel's servants - as her eyes dart around, seeking escape.*
Narrator: *Wyll shudders with Karlach's desperation. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Wyll: By Balduran's helm, I - no. I will not be tricked!
Karlach: You saw the truth. I may be an effective soldier, but I never wanted to serve Zariel. Legged it away from her the first chance I got.
Wyll: And yet you served.
Player: Stand down. You saw what I saw - Karlach is not a danger.
: False
Wyll: No. Devils can not be trusted!
Player: You saw Karlach's thoughts. She poses no threat to the Sword Coast.
Karlach: You know monsters better than anyone. Can't you look in my eyes and see I'm not a devil?
Wyll: You don't know what this means. You don't know what you're asking me to do.
Karlach: I'm asking you to live, Wyll. I don't want to hurt you. And, to be frank, I'd rather not find out how the Blade got his name.
Karlach: I swear to you, on all I am, I'm not what you think.
Wyll: Shit. Shit.
Wyll: You really are no devil, are you? I've... I've been deceived.

Narrator: *An ornate mace hovers before you, suspended in a shaft of brilliant light.*
Narrator: *A fist-sized piece of amber flecked with crimson is set in the handle, emitting a radiance all its own.*
: True
Narrator: *This mace must be the legendary Blood of Lathander - the amber is said to contain the blood of the Morninglord himself.*
Player: Reach into the light and take the mace.
Lae'zel: Stay your hand! The consequences may be more than we are ready to bear.
Gale: Are you quite sure that's wise?
Lae'zel: Step away. And banish this mace from your mind.
Narrator: *The glow around the mace sparkles with beautiful disaster.*
Narrator: *You recall all the measures meant to keep you from reaching this place.*
Narrator: *Taking this mace would surely lead to something quite disastrous.*
Narrator: *The brutal aches in your body yearn to take it, though you sense it will spell misfortune.*
Player: Claim the mace and delight in its danger.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I don't wish to study, only to lift the curse on this land.
Malus Thorm: A curse? Nay, a cure that leads to the very pinnacle of being:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I sought purpose in the natural world - I see now that Shar is the only path. Show me how - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Lorna Esthelian: Ah - a friendly face at last. Are you going to the party as well?
Player: A party in the sewers?
Lorna Esthelian: I know. Bit strange, isn't it? But then you have to be open to trying new things.
Lorna Esthelian: The venue's called 'The Palace'. Not sure what it stands for, but it sounds very exclusive.
Lorna Esthelian: My date's supposed to meet me here, but there's no sign of him.
Lorna Esthelian: You haven't seen him, have you? Pale, skinny - extremely piercing eyes.
: True
Narrator: *The individual descriptions could refer to many things, but taken together, she can only be referring to something vampiric in nature.*
Lorna Esthelian: It's funny. He was ever so keen for me to come. He didn't seem the type to cancel...
Player: What type did he seem?
Lorna Esthelian: Normal. Mostly. Didn't have much of an appetite at dinner, though he said he was saving himself for tonight.
Lorna Esthelian: He was so enthusiastic. I don't understand why he hasn't shown up...
Player: I'm sure he'll show up eventually.

Zenovia Dawg: Do you think you're clever coming in and undercutting us, sweetheart?
Zenovia Dawg: We were about to make a bit of extra cash before you butted in - you owe the Guild a cut.
Nightwarden Minthara: Is the little dog trying to intimidate us? If it continues to bark, I will snap its neck.
: True
Narrator: *The Guild: a loose coalition uniting every criminal outfit in the city under one collective rule, from cutpurses to contract killers.*
Player: I had a look in your employer's basement - did you know he puts explosives in children's toys?
Zenovia Dawg: And I'm the Duke's personal bed warmer. I don't care what pies he's got his grimy little fingers in - just give me the gold.
Player: How much gold are we talking?
Zenovia Dawg: Just a little something - consider it a gesture of good will. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: I'll pay you, but I need some time to get the gold together.
Zenovia Dawg: You think I'm just a pretty face? You'll pay up now - and just for trying it on, you can pay me double.
Player: Knock some sense into this upstart.
: True
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player swings at Zenovia and punches her (punch can be cut around to avoid showing actual contact)
Zenovia Dawg: That... was a mistake on your part, sweetie. A mistake the Guild will hear about.

Akabi: BEHOLD - AKABI'S WHEEL OF WONDERS.
Akabi: SPIN TO WIN PRIZES BEYOND YOUR TINY IMAGINATION, AND MAKE YOUR MISERABLE LIFE MORE BEARABLE. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: I'd like to spin the wheel.
Akabi: LET US SEE IF YOU HAVE LUCK'S FAVOUR.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The wheel spins.
: True
Narrator: *You notice a glint in Akabi's beard - as it glows, the wheel moves away from the 'jackpot'. He is cheating.*
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The wheel lands almost on the jackpot, but then passes it - on a random prize
Akabi: ALAS - NO JACKPOT FOR YOU, UGLY ONE. BUT YOU MAY HAVE THIS.
Player: You're cheating. I saw you rig the wheel.
Akabi: You dare speak to me as if we were equals? You are a scrap of food in my teeth. The dirt beneath my fingernails. You are nothing.
Akabi: I am, however, feeling gracious. So, I will forget this and allow you to spin again. Or I can turn you into something vile. Choose.
Player: Spin the wheel, watching for an opportunity to distract Akabi.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Shot of the wheel spinning
Player: I'd love to hear about the adventures of such a famous djinni.
: True
Akabi: AKABI IS MORE THAN A DJINNI. HE IS THE MOST MAGNIFICENT AND WONDROUS BEING IN THE REALMS. IN FACT -
NodeContext: player has tried to distract akabi, and it has worked. He's loudly and cheerfully talking about himself
Akabi: IMPOSSIBLE.
NodeContext: Akabi looks to his left in utter shock - horrified. The wheel has landed on the jackpot.
Akabi: YOU SNEAK. YOU CHEATED!
Akabi: YOU THIEF. YOU CHEATED.
Player: So did you - I just evened the odds.

Lora: My daughter's name is Vanra. We were in the Blushing Mermaid when she went missing.
Blaze Liara Portyr: Madam, tell me... you said... she was... ah... taken from a tavern?
NodeContext: struggling to get the words out - the memory is there but she just can't reach it
: True
Narrator: *You catch the barest tendrils of magic coiled around the Flaming Fist.*
Lora: Yes. The Blushing. Mermaid. Down by the docks. I've told you a hundred times - why aren't you listening?
Player: A hag took her - I saw it with my own eyes.
Lora: A hag has her? Gods above.
Lora: What does a hag want with Vanra? My poor child...
Player: If you can pay me, I'll help you.

Bex: Please, I just want to be alone.

Bex: Gone.
Bex: Cultists... It was so dark I didn't realise until the children started screaming.
Bex: They rounded us up... cut us up... Said they were taking whoever could still walk to Moonrise Towers.
Bex: I managed to get away, but my love Danis... Mar zindur vroshan.
Player: You think he's dead?
Bex: How couldn't he be?
Bex: If they didn't kill him when we ran, they probably will once they get to Moonrise.
Bex: I just wish I could have said goodbye.
Player: Danis could still be alive - don't give up on him yet.
Bex: Do you really think so? By the gods, I hope you're right.
Bex: I wish I hadn't let go of him.
Player: By the gods, I promise you I'll bring Danis back safely.

Efrin: Ungh... me head...
NodeContext: You were turned to stone and you're just coming out of it. Dazed, confused, touching your head.
Efrin: Oh no. No. Why ain't I petrified?

Efrin: I've the Bite...

Efrin: Better dead than a greyling. Why d'ya think we call it Laduguer's Bite? After that slaver of a god you adore?
Efrin: Because nothing disgusts us more than you lot.
Player: Laugh harder.

Narrator: *The lantern gives off a chilly glow, protecting all in its vicinity from the surrounding shadows.*
Harper Branthos: Incredible magic. I can feel the light lifting the shadows - even those within me.
Harper Branthos: Be safe. And be brave. We expect no less.

Dolly Dolly Dolly: This lantern only lights the way when I am hurting night and day!
Player: Who are you?
Dolly Dolly Dolly: My name? My name is Dolly thrice; now won't you free me from this vice?
Player: What's this mechanism at the base of the lantern?
Dolly Dolly Dolly: I dare not name it, newfound friend. The faintest touch could spell my end.
Player: Turn the mechanism.
Dolly Dolly Dolly: Son of a - NO! STOP! PLEASE!
Player: Ignore the pixie. You'll be needing this lamp.

Player: My, you've changed your tune.
Dolly Dolly Dolly: If you prefer the kinder type, I'll sweetly slurp your guts like tripe!
Player: Ignore the pixie; keep the lantern.

Narrator: *The guard insists that you meet with their leader - a Harper by the name of Jaheira.*
InternalNodeContext: Player was sneaking inside but was discovered by someone. Jaheira was called in crime dialog.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: | (CINE) Jaheira approaches. Haper Elifer is about to speak, but a stern glance from Jaheira shuts them up and makes them cast her eyes to the ground. Jaheira then directs her stern glance at us. Without a word she raises her right hand claw-like to chest height. Magic ripples and entangling vines start to sprout from the ground, trapping the party in place. Onlooking Harpers draw their swords. |
Player: Holy shit. It's really you. The Jaheira.
Jaheira: You have me at a disadvantage. Let me correct that.
Jaheira: Hello.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Harpers draw their weapons.
Player: Please - ma'am - I'm from Baldur's Gate. Like you. I'm on your side.
Jaheira: I'll be the judge of that.
Jaheira: This is why we're here, you see.
NodeContext: Her calm menace continues. She’s about to make a demonstration.
Jaheira: It is a curious creature that hides all manner of secrets. But if there's one thing that we know -
NodeContext: Her calm menace continues. She’s about to make a demonstration.
Jaheira: - it's that it knows its own kind.

| (CINE) Her suspicions now confirmed, Jaheira stows away the jar. The onlooking Harpers eye us with a mixture of fear and hatred. |
NodeContext: Her calm menace continues. The demonstration is done and she’s proved her point: we’re the enemy because we have a tadpole in our heads.
Jaheira: You should never have come here, True Soul.
NodeContext: Grave. She’s passing a death sentence on us.
Player: I am not... a True Soul...
Mol: Stop!

| (CINE) Jaheira glances over as a small figure pushes through the Harpers. It's Mol. |
Mol: What are you doing? They're the ones that saved us!
Jaheira: They're the one who protected the Emerald Grove?
Mol: Yup. Didn't leave a goblin standing. Not so bad to hang around with either.
Mol: Saved two of my friends - one from a harpy, and one from a mad druid with a snake. Didn't make a fuss of our thieving, either.
Mol: I'd pretty much trust them with my life.
Jaheira: A True Soul with a mind of their own... How is that possible?
Jaheira: How is that possible?
Player: You'll just have to take my word for it.
Jaheira: You sound so confident for someone who's so wrong.
Player: Fine - here. (Show Jaheira the artefact.)
[description] CinematicNodeContext: | (CINE) The player takes Orpheus from their pocket and presents it to Jaheira who looks on intrigued. She takes out the jar again and we see the tadpole flail wildly inside - then the jar explodes and the tadpole drops to the ground dead. There are gasps from the crowd, and several of the Harpers move in to strike us down. |
Jaheira: What in the hells is that thing?
Player: Your guess is as good as mine.
Jaheira: Strangest magic I've seen since roaming the ruins of Myth Drannor, but I can't argue with the results.
Jaheira: Congratulations. You've earned yourself the benefit of the doubt.
Jaheira: Hear me, Harpers! All clear, at ease!
[description] CinematicNodeContext: | (CINE) Those Harpers who still had their weapons drawn stow them way. The tension among them dissipates now that Jaheira has cleared us. |
Jaheira: I'll not pretend to understand why you, the enigma that you are, suddenly crossed our path, but I'm old and wise enough to recognise a sliver of hope when it crawls out of the dark.
Jaheira: Tell me - why have you come here?
Player: I'm here on holiday.

The Warden: You. Not you. Lord Ketheric may think you pose no threat to him in your disgrace, but I know the things you've done.
The Warden: Keep your bloody thoughts to yourself and your head down.
Player: How in the Hells do you know me?
The Warden: You set foot in our tower once. You did not leave, at least not through any door I have watch over.
The Warden: I assumed you overstayed your welcome. Little did I expect you to intrude again.
The Warden: Your name, your place was kept from all of us last time, but you were to be shown the utmost of respect.
The Warden: Respect you must have proven yourself unworthy of. And now you waste my time.
The Warden: Hm. Perhaps not - your face is rather bland.
The Warden: Whatever your business, a warning: none may speak to the prisoners - Disciple Balthazar was most clear.
Player: The rules don't apply to me.

The Warden: I'm not sure why someone of your stature must converse with prisoners. Perhaps a small donation would convince me.

The Warden: Pockets running a little empty, are they?
The Warden: Disciple Balthazar's orders still stand - none may speak to the prisoners. You can go now.
The Warden: The Absolute thanks you for this generous donation, True Soul. You can go now.

Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: My ardents spoke of one of our kin that escaped a crashing ghaik slave-vessel.
Lae'zel: Ch'r'ai. Vlaakith's justice in flesh.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much, child. I am pleased to finally meet you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Interesting. My ardents reported that an istik survived the crashed ghaik slave-vessel.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much since. I am pleased to finally meet you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I heard there is so much goblin blood on your hands that it soaks their children's nightmares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Kith'rak Voss' made a mistake when he let you go.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: To business. I suspect you plucked something precious from the ghaik ship. Something that belongs to us.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The weapon. Give it to me.

Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The weapon. Now.

NodeContext: Bemused, snarky

Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: So. The weapon. Please.

NodeContext: Goblin throws the bone into the shadows

InternalNodeContext: The hyena chases the bone into the shadow curse and disappears into the darkness. After a moment you hear a growl, then a yelp and a *crunch* as the animal's killed (all out of sight).
Warrior Gronag: Heh. Oi!
Warrior Gronag: Heh. You see that blighter go? Swallowed whole by the shadow curse. Bet he was pure tasty.
Warrior Gronag: You're the True Soul we're taking to Moonrise, I'm guessing?

Warrior Gronag: Talk to Kansif inside - he'll run through it.

Warrior Gronag: But we're ready to go. You just need to tell Kansif inside.

Warrior Gronag: So you want me to... I mean, I'll just-...

Karlach: Could have sworn I told you to piss off. Maybe I imagined it.

Player: They said you're a fiend, that you belong in hell.
Karlach: If you killed them, I'm guessing you didn't buy their bullshit.
Karlach: I don't belong in hell any more than you do. But I was there.
Narrator: *As she winces, agony shoots through you, as if your bodies share the same wound.*
Narrator: *Then you're lost in visions of demonic armies, as you tear through a landscape of fire and blood.*
Narrator: *The Blood War. You saw it from above as the nautiloid passed through Avernus - this woman was on the frontline.*
Karlach: Ster'ca. What was that? You were inside my head...

Player: It wasn't me - it's the parasites from the mind flayer ship. They connected us.
Karlach: Hold on a minute - you were on that ship? With the tentacles, and the worms?
Karlach: I didn't think anyone else had survived.
Player: I didn't see you aboard. Where were you?
Karlach: I boarded in Avernus - that ship was my way out.
Player: You must have got clear of the crash site in a hurry.
Karlach: You're lucky I did.
Karlach: The place would have been crawling with cultists if I'd stuck around - and they'd have dragged us all back to Avernus.
Karlach: And I'll be going straight back if those imp-fuckers catch me.
Player: Why were you in hell in the first place?
Karlach: I was a prisoner, forced to fight in the Blood War - the eternal battle between bad and worse.
Karlach: Most souls in Avernus are just meat for the grinder. But not me.
Karlach: I held my own. More than. Turns out I've got a knack for killing demons - and I enjoy it. That made me a valuable asset.
Karlach: Devils don't like to lose their assets.
Player: Judging by the wound, I'm guessing they already found you.
Karlach: Yeah. Not far from here - gang of cultists cornered me in an abandoned tollhouse.
Karlach: I took out a couple, but I need them all dead.
Player: I'll look into it.

Narrator: *Calmness greets you as the submersible slows to a halt. Unlike the Iron Throne, you remain intact.*
Narrator: *It seems most of the hostages from the Throne share your fate.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You acted quickly, decisively, and compassionately. I - nay, all of us - owe you no less than our undying gratitude.
Player: The Absolute's voice has gone silent. It must be a relief.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: The... the Absolute. Its voice was clear as crystal, beautiful as a nymph's smile. It showed me the darkest lies and convinced me of their truth.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: To be free is like knowing the sun's warmth on my face for the first time.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My thoughts are my own now, and my purpose certain. I will wait at your camp - we can speak more there.

Lorna Esthelian: Ah - a friendly face at last. Are you going to the party as well?
Player: A party in the sewers?
Lorna Esthelian: I know. Bit strange, isn't it? But then you have to be open to trying new things.
Lorna Esthelian: The venue's called 'The Palace'. Not sure what it stands for, but it sounds very exclusive.
Lorna Esthelian: My date's supposed to meet me here, but there's no sign of him.
Lorna Esthelian: You haven't seen him, have you? Pale, skinny - extremely piercing eyes.
Lorna Esthelian: Looks a bit like you, actually.
Lorna Esthelian: It's funny. He was ever so keen for me to come. He didn't seem the type to cancel...
Player: Did he say what kind of party it's supposed to be?
Lorna Esthelian: Only that it was him and a few of his closest friends. Said he couldn't wait to introduce me to them - how often does a man say that to a girl he's only met once?
Lorna Esthelian: He was so enthusiastic. I don't understand why he hasn't shown up...
Player: I'm sure he'll show up eventually.

Araj Oblodra: Welcome back, True Soul.
Araj Oblodra: I read about your kind for so many years, but never thought I'd find one in real life. And to find such a fine specimen...
Astarion: Don't worry, we're all friends under the Absolute. I won't bite.
Araj Oblodra: Oh I'd prefer if you did.
Araj Oblodra: I assume he belongs to you?
Player: Excuse me? He's his own person.
Araj Oblodra: I'm sure he really believes that. How utterly adorable.
Araj Oblodra: Do you have a name, spawn?
Astarion: Astarion, but hold on-
Araj Oblodra: Good. Now, Astarion, I've dreamt of being bitten by a vampire since I was a young girl.
Astarion: I'm sorry? You want to be bitten?
Araj Oblodra: To feel your life's blood slipping away? To dance on the edge between life and death? Yes, I want it.
Araj Oblodra: I'll even compensate you - a potion of legendary power that forever increases the strength of the one who consumes it.
Araj Oblodra: It's not for sale, but it's yours if you bite me.
Astarion: I will have to decline.
Araj Oblodra: Excuse me? This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity and you're squandering it.
Astarion: I gave you my answer.
Araj Oblodra: Can't you talk some sense into your obstinate charge?
Player: Just bite her - the potion sounds useful.
Astarion: I'm sorry, but could you excuse us a moment?
Astarion: Are you actually asking me to do this? Trading me for some potion?
Astarion: Because there's something wrong with her blood. I can smell it from here - it's rank.
Player: What do you mean? What's wrong with her blood?
Astarion: I can't say, it just smells wrong. Unnatural.
Astarion: Drinking it wouldn't kill me, but it would not be pleasant.
Araj Oblodra: I don't have all day, True Soul.
Player: Don't do anything you don't want to.
Astarion: All right. Thank you.

Raphael: Do you know what happens when a devil is struck down on this charming plane of existence?
Raphael: It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on.
Raphael: In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope.
Raphael: He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored.
Raphael: He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.

Player: Please, give me more boring details about your plans.
Raphael: Come now, we're about to unveil your destiny - you should be quivering in anticipation.

Raphael: And why would he want to walk away? This is his destiny.
Raphael: As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr.
Raphael: In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed.
Raphael: The Rite of Profane Ascension.
Raphael: It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical.
Raphael: If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant.
Raphael: All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living.
Raphael: The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike you, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun.
Raphael: But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend.
Raphael: Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air.
Raphael: The only missing ingredient is Astarion.
Raphael: You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life.
Raphael: And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.

Astarion: I wasn't going to hurt you! I just needed - well, blood.

Astarion: I only need a taste, I swear.

Raphael: The only missing ingredient is Astarion.

Raphael: As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr.
Raphael: In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed.
Raphael: The Rite of Profane Ascension.
Raphael: It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical.
Raphael: If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant.
Raphael: All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living.
Raphael: The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike Astarion, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun.
Raphael: But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend.
Raphael: Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air.
Raphael: The only missing ingredient is Astarion.
Raphael: You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life.
Raphael: And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.

Araj Oblodra: It's not for sale, but it's yours if you bite me.
